div.p: Greetings. I have finally completed the books I wrote against the Anabaptists, and for which reason I have sent you letters less frequently for quite some time now. I am now sending the book itself and thus try to make amends for what you might have complained was lacking in my diligence. I overwhelm you with my writings; however, I do not think you need them, but since I usually send my works to my closest friends, and you are among the first and oldest friends, I cannot help but share mine with you. Please consider it kindly, I pray.

You would do a most welcome thing if you would kindly inform me what seems to you more correct or more convenient or even should be proposed differently. Indeed, I have compiled many things in this work in a short time; I pray to the Lord that all these things may contribute to His glory and the salvation of many. From France, we hear of strange disturbances arising.

There are among the princes and nobles those who wish to free the king from the rule and tyranny of the cardinal and the Guise family; the French do not like that the Lorrainers sit on their heads. The constable has long since left the court; the King of Navarre is also scorned; other princes are forced to see what they do not want: therefore, friends now write that I do not know what the French princes and nobles are planning, from which a remarkable change must necessarily arise, etc. Let us pray to the Lord that things turn out well.
It is strange why so many companies of soldiers are being gathered throughout Germany, if what I hear is true. If you have any information, please share it.
Master Burcher has not yet returned, perhaps he will return with the merchants coming back from Frankfurt. All of mine greet you; greet your family.
Wilhelm Stucki has gone to Master Hubert, so that he may be a companion to your son.
